page.title: 02ROSSINGTON PIT
page.content: Rossington grew rapidly in size when the pit was sunk in 1912 and many new jobs were created. Coal was first produced in 1915. Today five coal faces produce 18,000 tons weekly, mainly for the Yorkshire Power Stations. The pit employs 1725 people including management staff. Two Rossington miners describe where they work - "Rossington Pit has two shafts. Number 1 shaft takes in fresh air and also has two lifts which have 3 decks, each deck carries 27 men up or down. The shaft is also used for carrying equipment in and out ,and carries electric and telephone cables, water and air pipes and air monitoring tubes. Number 2 or Return Air shaft has two lifts or skips which can carry 10 tons of coal or men in an emergency".
